TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . At DATE the police division responsible for fighting organised crime and drug trafficking ( “ the police ” ) received information that the applicant and his friends GPE and GPE were trafficking in drugs . The CARDINAL friends were ecstasy users . At the time of the events , the applicant and GPE were students .

CARDINAL . On DATE the police sought authorisation from the prosecutor 's office to use undercover agents and a collaborator to follow the lead regarding the suspects ' alleged criminal activities . On DATE the organised crime and drug - trafficking section of the prosecutor 's office at ORG ( “ the prosecutor 's office ” ) authorised CARDINAL agents , referred to in the proceedings as “ PERSON and “ PERSON ” ( the latter being introduced to the applicant and his friends as “ PERSON ) , and a collaborator , “ PERSON , to participate in the operation .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON met the applicant , GPE and PERSON in a restaurant ( “ restaurant E ” ) and agreed to meet with them again DATE .

CARDINAL . At TIME the applicant and PERSON were sitting with PERSON on the terrace of restaurant M and GPE was sitting at the adjacent table with some friends , when plain clothes police officers rose from the neighbouring tables and arrested the CARDINAL suspects . A yellow plastic bag was taken from under the applicant 's table and its contents checked ; the police noted that it contained bread , under which were several packets fastened with brown tape which together contained CARDINAL white tablets which later proved to be ecstasy .
CARDINAL . The CARDINAL suspects were arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking . The police took photographs and videotaped the events . Images from the operation were shown on the evening news .

CARDINAL . On her arrest GPE confessed to the prosecutor that she and PERSON had taken part in drug trafficking . However , she withdrew her confessions before the firstinstance court , claiming that she had been coerced into making them by the police with the promise that if she wrote down what she was told to write , she would be released after TIME .

CARDINAL . The applicant and his friends claimed that they had been contacted by ORG , whose real name was PERSON , and who was a friend of GPE They gave the authorities his full name and address for further investigation . PERSON had told them that ORG had various objects ( clothes and watches ) for sale at reasonable prices . They finally agreed to meet PERSON and at TIME on CARDINAL DATE they , together with PERSON , went to restaurant PERSON They sat down with PERSON , who did not have the merchandise with him . Later that day the CARDINAL friends were at bar N. when PERSON told them that PERSON was at restaurant M and could meet them again . The applicant and PERSON left in PERSON 's car . After a while , they called GPE and GPE , who had stayed behind , and told them that PERSON had forgotten a yellow plastic bag under their table at the bar and asked them if they could bring it to restaurant M as it contained food for PERSON 's wife , who was ill .

CARDINAL . At TIME the applicant and PERSON arrived at restaurant M and sat at PERSON 's table . TIME later PERSON , who was carrying PERSON 's plastic bag , and GPE , joined them . PERSON sat at PERSON 's table while GPE sat at the next table with some acquaintances .
CARDINAL . When PERSON went to the toilet , plainclothes police officers intervened , expecting to find exactly CARDINAL tablets of ecstasy in the bag under the table .

CARDINAL . In their statements , the applicant and his friends insisted that the drugs had in fact been given to the undercover agents by the police for the purpose of the covert operation . In support of their statements they pointed out that despite their constant surveillance over DATE the police could not explain where the friends had obtained the drugs .

CARDINAL . The applicant and his friends were arrested and taken into custody on TIME of DATE , on suspicion of trafficking in drugs . Their detention was maintained by the courts throughout the proceedings .

CARDINAL . NORP The prosecutor 's office heard evidence from the applicant , GPE and GPE , and from CARDINAL eyewitnesses who had been present on the terrace at restaurant M , and examined the written records of statements by PERSON and PERSON . At the prosecutor 's request , both the applicant 's and GPE 's flats were searched by the police . No drugs or other illegal substances were found .

The prosecutor concluded that on DATE PERSON had informed PERSON that the QUANTITY persons were preparing a transaction involving ORG tablets ( methylenedioxymethamphetamine ) . PERSON had then contacted PERSON , who had met with the suspects to secure the transaction . According to PERSON 's statements , the suspects had offered to sell him CARDINAL tablets of MDMA for MONEY each .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office committed the applicant , GPE and GPE for trial on charges of drug - trafficking , in violation of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the fight against drug trafficking and illegal drug use ( “ Law no . CARDINAL ” ) .

CARDINAL . It also decided to sever the criminal investigations from those concerning another participant in the trafficking , PERSON , who had not yet been identified by the police . On CARDINAL DATE , the prosecutor 's office at ORG identified PERSON as being the same person as PERSON and closed the investigation against him .
CARDINAL . Several hearings were held before ORG .

CARDINAL . The CARDINAL accused denied their involvement in drug trafficking and claimed that they had been entrapped by the police . They repeatedly stated that PERSON had also been present at restaurant PERSON

CARDINAL . The defence lawyers insisted on the importance for the court of hearing evidence from PERSON in the presence of the defendants . They also requested the police to produce the bag and the packets in which the tablets had been found and to collect fingerprints from them . They considered that the court should see the video tapes of the events . Lastly , they asked for a confrontation between the applicants , which would allow them to prove that the police had put pressure on them and made them promises in order to obtain the initial declarations .
The court did not hear that evidence .

CARDINAL . ORG gave judgment on DATE . It found the CARDINAL accused guilty of drug trafficking and sentenced them DATE imprisonment . It deducted from the sentence the time spent in pretrial detention . The court also confiscated the CARDINAL tablets of MDMA that were left after laboratory tests had been carried out .

CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the defence arguments on the ground that under PERSON no . CARDINAL statements made by undercover agents and their collaborators can constitute evidence . The court was satisfied that those statements had not been obtained illegally and considered that the defence argument to the contrary could not taint the evidence . It also considered that the intention of the accused to sell drugs was evidenced by their entering into negotiations with PERSON , which in turn led to their authorising PERSON to make the transaction with the defendants and obtain the drugs from them .

In reaching its conclusion , ORG relied on the statements made by the suspects and the undercover agents PERSON and PERSON to the police , as well as the declarations made by the applicant before the court . It gave precedence to the statement given by GPE during the investigations as it considered that her withdrawal of her initial statement to the police was unjustified , as she had not proved that she had been coerced into making it .

CARDINAL . All the parties appealed against the judgment of DATE . The defence counsel reiterated that the evidence gathered against the defendants was illegal , that the drugs had belonged to the police and that PERSON should be heard by the court .

CARDINAL . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld ORG findings on the facts of the case and its examination of the participants ' guilt . It considered , however , that ORG had erred in determining the sentence , in that it had not taken into account the seriousness of the crimes committed and the fact that , as students , the participants had a higher level of education which should have allowed them to comprehend the gravity of their deeds . It therefore increased the sentence to DATE imprisonment for each defendant .
CARDINAL . In a final decision of DATE ORG and ORG dismissed the defendants ' appeals in cassation and upheld ORG decision .
